original_title: Sri Lanka trains more female gantry crane operators
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT- Sri Lanka has trained eight female gantry operators helping boost female employment in a non-traditional area, Minister of Ports and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva has said.

“Women in Sri Lanka are generally engaged in conservative jobs such as nursing, teaching profession, clerical, and are happy to be able to change from that conservative form and direct them to technical jobs such as the naval field,” Minister of Aviation and Ports, Nimal Siripala said.
It is believed that women will be able to be attracted to these fields in the future.”
State-run Sri Lanka Ports Authority started employing lady gantry crane operators in 2017 and is South Asia’s First Team of Female Gantry Crane Operators is seen in the island.
They will work alongside the first 10 female gantry crane operators who have been in the field for over six years.
“These newly trained gantry crane operators are in high demand for job opportunities in the private sector and container terminals in foreign countries,” Minister de Silva said.

This job role has broken the social norm because mostly these crane operations are handled by men, this particular field has changed that whole perspective by giving the opportunity to women to take part in this role as operators.
The eight young women had completed the gantry crane course at the Mahpola Port and Maritime Academy.

“This program was always there for decades but it was the men who were doing the courses related to the gantry cranes but now we have changed as we have given opportunity for 8 females”, Akila Gayan the Private Secretary the minister said.
“The training started two months ago because it’s a 50-hour program and the program ran for about 3 months. we are promoting more women to operate gantry crane operators.”

Gantry cranes are at the heart of efficient port operations and it is a highly skilled and demanding job. Efficient gantry crane operators are globally sought after and many Sri Lankan gantry operators work in Middle Eastern ports.
According to an international study females were found to be more focused and there is interest borne by women to engage in such job roles, Gayan said.
The project was initiated in collaboration with International Labor Organization (ILO) and National Union of Seafarers Sri Lanka (NUSS).

“The program lasted three months and now we have gained our technical experience and work on shift basis, changing between morning or night shifts,” one of the female gantry crane operators told EconomyNext.
In December 2022, President Wickremesinghe proposed a new bill on gender equality and women’s empowerment to be submitted to parliament.
In Sri Lanka, critics say violence against women is not dealt with the seriousness it demands.

Females account for 51.8 percent of the entire population of 22 million however the labor force participation rate stands to be 34.47 percent for 2021 as per statistics from the World Bank Development Indicators. (Colombo/Apr11/2023)
